data.title: Tallest Load-Bearing Brick Building
data.text: The building is open to the public and you can walk through - and also go up stairs.  It is the tallest load-bearing brick building ever constructed (north section built in 1891 and the south in 1893).  The shops inside are also interesting - especially the custom made hat shop.  We went on a 45 minute tour of the building as part of the Chicago Architecture Foundation.  Great structure and wonderfully restored.

data.title: Masterpiece Office Buildling
data.text: This building is one of the must-see with my architect friends. Just like many other tall buildings in Chicago, you have to step back at least a block away to get a good photo.

data.title: What a building!
data.text: This is another of Chicago's famous, historic buildings. Be sure to walk through, end to end and see the shops. It is like stepping back in time!  So glad this building has been saved.

data.title: 1861 Office Building
data.text: My mother worked in this building back in the 50's so we went to revisit it with her.  Specialty shops on the ground floor take you back nearly a century with a hat store that makes custom made hats and a shoe shine store that repairs shoes.  The jewelry store has been around for over 50 years as well.  The Intellegentsia coffee shop is in the same place as the cafe where my mother used to buy breakfast.  We rode the elevator up to the 8th floor where she worked on the switchboard.  The beautiful staircases are still the same and if you take a peek behind the women's bathroom, you'll find another set of hidden stairs where the men's restroom used to be.  The mail shoots on each floor and mail boxes on the ground floor haven't changed as well as the tiling on the floors.  Well worth a visit.

data.title: Amazing Artwork in Lobby
data.text: This building is worth at least a quick visit to the lobby off State Street (open to the public) to see the amazing mosaic artwork inside that tells an historical story, although you'll have to research what it is. Just walk in and look up.

data.title: cool passage
data.text: This is actually two buildings into one, with a nice hallway passage between them. There are really cool shops here, like an old style barber and shoe repair. The mail boxes are great works of art, don't miss those. It is an amazing gem in the loop.

data.title: Iconic, would be cool to see!
data.text:
From the outside, it was cool! (its free to see it from the outside). 
If you want to see it from the inside well your out of luck unless you've got an apt with someone in the building.

data.title: Visit the shops in this gem of a building
data.text: I discovered the beauty of this structure when I visited the Florodora dress and shoe shops on the south end of the building (ladies, peruse the stores, they're pricey but feature local designers and beautiful merchandise). When you walk through the interior you can appreciate the architecture as well as the turn of the century vibe the shops inspire.  You'll find a hatmaker, shoe repair, flower shop, coffee shop, restaurant, old fashioned barber shop and the Florodora boutiques inside. Don't miss the enormous and beautifully embellished mail box as you enter from the north end on Jackson. Read up on the building's history and look at it from Dearborn St. You'll find the north and south ends were built at different times. Get a taste of what 1940s Chicago was. The type of businesses here probably havent changed much since.

data.title: I only saw outside - would love to see inside next time!
data.text: This building is a little deceptive. It has been restored and renovated many times during its existence, and looks rather modern at first sight. In fact it was built in the Victorian era, in one of the gaps left after the great fire of Chicago, with construction starting in 1891. One thing I appreciated was the cast-iron work on the outside as shown in the accompanying photograph, but if you are able to go inside, you will see some beautiful mosaic tiling and woodwork. A must for your Chicago skyscraper tour!

data.title: Must See - Chicago Architecture
data.text:
The building is beautiful and it's history intriguing.  In short, the northern part exemplified the masonry construction where walls support the building and the southern part, blending perfectly, the steel support technique.  I'll leave details about the architects careers and historical specifics for the genuinely interested architecture affectionado to discover.  Inside are remarkable staircases.  Pictures...you need pictures, not words.

Currently the building has everything from upscale designer boutiques to conservation foundations to many law offices among its occupants.  Offices have large glass windows giving light and charm and a view out into Chicago.

Although ot on the area's walking architecture tour, you can walk through the building's ground retail floor and see its details at your leisure during business hours. Must See!

data.title: Architectural gem
data.text: This is one of the most famous buildings of my architecture education.  The Monadnock Building was the world's largest office building when it was finished in 1893.  It's a masonry masterpiece and is supported by the material (brick) it's made of, not a hidden steel structure like most other buildings are today.  The walls on the street level are about six feet thick to support the upper stories.  It's been restored and there are some cool shops and a couple of restaurants inside.  I highly recommend a visit and at least a walk through this historic architectural gem.

data.title: 벽에 무게를 지탱해서 만든 고층건물
data.text: 바로 철근으로 뼈대를 세운 것이 아니라, 벽에 무게를 지탱해서 세운 무려 16층 짜리 고층빌딩입니다. 1891년에 지어진 이 빌딩은 세계에서 가장 오래된 상업 건물로 현재도 렌트 중입니다. 건축에 관심있는 분은 시카고에서 반드시 보아야할 건물 중 하나입니다.

data.title: Первое высотное здание
data.text: Прогуливаясь по финансовому району, посмотрите на здание Monadnock. Из путеводителя следует, что это первое высотное здание с лифтом, которое было построено в Чикаго. После этого здания уже строили здания с металлическим каркасом. Любопытно будет посмотреть, как раньше смотрелись "первые небоскребы". Внутрь здания не заходила.

data.title: Историческое здание
data.text: Один из последних полностью кирпичных небоскребов в Чикаго, построен в 1893 г. После этого строили уже с металлическим каркасом. Обратите внимание на толщину стен, увеличенную на первом этаже до 1,8 м! И очень низкий 1 этаж: из-за веса здание погрузилось в землю. Форма окон также необычная, такие окна стали делать здесь, их прозвали ''Чикагские окна''.

data.title: Dove inizia la storia dei grattacieli
data.text: A vederlo oggi, questo edificio sembra un palazzetto basso affossato tra i grandi e alti grattacieli di Chicago, poi sta pure poco distante dalla Willis Tower (ex Sears Tower) che svetta a quasi mezzo chilometro di altezza. In realtà questo palazzo è stato costruito nell'Ottocento, interamente in mattoni e con pareti spesse circa un metro e mezzo. Conta solo sedici piani, ma per quel tempo era praticamente un record. In pratica con la costruzione di questo edificio si è dato inizio alla storia dei grattacieli. Va quindi visto a mio parere anche con un po' di fantasia e cercando di immaginare cosa fosse Chicago in quegli anni.
